contents.context:
The World Bank had added South Korea to its list of so-called 'emergency care countries'.
Seoul will now offer immediate medical care to the group's employees in the East Asia and Pacific region with acute or life-threatening conditions, if local hospitals are unable to provide them with treatment.
The decision was reportedly made because of South Korea's COVID-19 response and its trustworthy medical system.
South Korea is only the third Asian country on the list after Thailand and Singapore.
Reporter : tkim@arirang.com
contents.headline:
World Bank adds S. Korea to its emergency care countries list
Updated: 2020-06-10 09:51:53 KST

contents.context:
World leaders won't gather in New York City for the annual UN General Assembly in September in light of the COVID-19 pandemic.
This is the first time the hall won't be used for the assembly in the UN's 75 year history.
The president of UN General Assembly said during a press conference this week that it's impossible for world leaders to come as they need to bring large delegations.
He added that the UN hopes to find a way for the leaders to give speeches and commemorate the 75th anniversary of the UN's foundation.
Reporter : reina5467@gmail.com
contents.headline:
World leaders told not to come to NYC for this year's UN General Assembly due to COVID-19
Updated: 2020-06-10 09:51:41 KST

contents.context:
The final funeral service for African American George Floyd, whose death at the hands of a white police officer ignited anti-racism protests around the world was held in the U.S. on Tuesday, local time.
At the Fountain of Praise church, in Houston, Texas George Floyd's hometown hundreds of mourners consoled each other as they eulogized Mr. Floyd.
It has been 15-days since Mr. Floyd was killed in Minneapolis.
Several dignitaries and celebrities were in attendance as well.
Former Vice President and 2020 Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden shared his condolences via a video message.
The mayor of the city declared June 9th as George Floyd Day in Houston.
Reporter : reina5467@gmail.com
contents.headline:
Final funeral service for George Floyd held in Houston
Updated: 2020-06-10 07:45:24 KST

contents.context:
UN human rights experts are urging Japan against rushing to discharge radioactive water from the Fukushima nuclear plant into the sea, stressing Tokyo has to hold consultations with affected communities and its neighboring countries beforehand.
In a press release Tuesday, the experts raised concerns that the Japanese government has accelerated its timeline for the release without time or opportunity for "meaningful" consultations.
The experts want Tokyo to delay its decision until after the COVID-19 pandemic has passed, so proper attention can be dedicated to the issue.
Reporter : seungjae86@gmail.com
contents.headline:
UN human rights experts urge Japan to hold off on radioactive water discharge into sea
Updated: 2020-06-10 05:57:35 KST

contents.context:
Thousands of mourners stand in line at The Fountain of Praise church in Houston on Monday to pay their respects to George Floyd.
It's the final memorial that is open for the public.
Visitors were wearing masks and maintaining distance from each other to prevent the spread of COVID-19.
Floyd's brother, Philonise Floyd, made a statement at the visitation ceremony.

"It just hurts a lot just being here, talking. Just pain. Thank you all, so much for coming out to support us."

The families of Eric Garner and Michael Brown, and other victims of racism and police brutality, attended the service.
Presumptive Democratic nominee Joe Biden and Texas Governor Greg Abbott also met the family of George Floyd to express solidarity.
Governor Abbott hinted that there could be a George Floyd Act to prevent police brutality in Texas.
As protests are ongoing nationwide, many stores that have been looted are worried about recovering from the damage.
A sports store owner in New York expressed his concerns.

"The televisions, cameras everything I've installed in here, the interior it's all smashed up. Almost a million dollars gone in just one morning. It's so disappointing. I never imagined this could happen."

Meanwhile, things are quietening down in Los Angeles, and the National Guard left LA's Koreatown and some other parts of the city on Monday.
Jang Tae-hyun, Arirang News
Reporter : tommyjang@arirang.com
contents.headline:
Mourners pay respects to George Floyd in Houston
Updated: 2020-06-09 17:05:20 KST

contents.context:
In January, the World Bank forecast 2.5 percent growth for the global economy in 2020.
Then the COVID-19 pandemic swept the world.
On Monday, the World Bank released its revised outlook for 2020, forecasting the global economy to shrink 5.2 percent.
According to the World Bank, the current crisis is the deepest global recession since World War Two, and almost three times as bad as the 2009 global recession.
Also, more advanced economies are projected to shrink by 7-percent, due to widespread of social distancing measures, a sharp tightening of financial conditions, and a huge decline in exports.
This includes China, where the COVID-19 outbreak originated.
It's projected to see a 1-percent growth this year, the lowest growth it has registered in more than four decades.
However, the World Bank's forecast was made under the assumption that the pandemic recedes by mid-year, and negative global spillovers ease during the second half of the year.
Meanwhile, a group of economists said on Monday,.. that the U.S. economy entered a recession in February, ending its longest expansion on record.
They say the number of employed Americans peaked in February and fell sharply afterwards, marking the start of the downturn.
The definition of a recession according to the economists, is a "decline in economic activity that lasts more than a few months", hence their February remark.
Despite its gloomy outlook for 2020, the World Bank expressed optimism that 2021 will see the global economy bounce back, predicting 4.2 percent growth.
But other analysts say there won't be a rebound unless a vaccine for COVID-19 is available before the end of the year.
Lee Seung-jae, Arirang News.

Reporter : seungjae86@gmail.com
contents.headline:
World Bank forecasts world economy to contract 5.2% in 2020
Updated: 2020-06-09 10:05:21 KST

contents.context:
The chief of the WHO has urged protesters around the world to wear face masks, adding that he supports the global movement against racism.

(ENGLISH)- AP 4273027 / 2
"WHO fully supports equality and the global movement against racism. We reject discrimination of all kinds. We encourage all those protesting around the world to do so safely. As much as possible, keep at least one meter from others. Clean your hands, cover your cough and wear a mask if you attend a protest. We remind all people to stay home if you're sick and contact a health care provider."

During a news conference Monday, Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus also called on countries to stay vigilant.
He stressed it's not the time to take their collective foot off the pedal, explaining that over 136-thousand cases were reported worldwide on Sunday, the most in a single day so far.
He added that a majority of Sunday's cases were concentrated in 10 countries, mostly in the Americas and South Asia.
Noting that many countries had identified asymptomatic cases in the process of contact tracing, a senior WHO official explained they need to focus on patients with symptoms.

(ENGLISH) AP 4273027 / 2
"It still appears to be rare that an asymptomatic individual actually transmits onward. What we really want to be focused on is following the symptomatic cases. If we followed all of the symptomatic cases because we know that this is a respiratory pathogen. It passes from an individual through infectious droplets."

The WHO stressed that finding, isolating, testing and caring for every case is crucial, adding countries need to continue to trace and quarantine every contact, and never drop their guard.
Kim Hyo-sun, Arirang News.
Reporter : hyosunee88@gmail.com
contents.headline:
WHO chief calls on protesters around world to wear masks, maintain distance
Updated: 2020-06-09 09:49:56 KST

contents.context:
Responding to a report saying the Trump administration is considering whether to pull U.S. troops out of Germany, the White House press secretary said there's no announcements to be made, but didn't deny the reports.
Speaking at a press briefing at the White House on Monday, Kayleigh McEnany said President Trump is "continually reassessing the best posture for U.S. military forces and its presence overseas", hinting at ongoing defense cost sharing negotiations with countries where American troops are stationed.
The Wall Street Journal reported last Friday, that President Trump ordered the removal of around 9,5-hundred U.S. troops in Germany where more than 34-thousand are assigned.
Reporter : reina5467@gmail.com
contents.headline:
No announcements to be made on cutting around 9,500 U.S. troops stationed in Germany: White House
Updated: 2020-06-09 07:59:06 KST

contents.context:
Now to U.S. politics, a new CNN poll shows the presumptive Democratic nominee Joe Biden has taken a 14-point lead over President Trump as protests continue around the United States and the COVID-19 pandemic continues to take lives.
Taken between June 2nd and the 5th the poll shows President Trump's approval has slumped 38-percent, the lowest level since January last year, and his disapproval rate had reached to 57-percent.
The new poll also found Biden with 55 percent, his highest mark yet.
Following the release of the CNN poll, President Trump labeled it 'fake.'
Reporter : ashin@arirang.co.kr
contents.headline:
Biden takes 14-point lead over Trump in new CNN poll for presidential election
Updated: 2020-06-09 05:57:00 KST

contents.context:
New York City, the U.S. city hit hardest by the COVID-19 pandemic, entered Phase One of a four-phase reopening plan on Monday, as it begins the slow process of rebuilding its economy.
The first phase sees as many as 400-thousand workers resume their jobs in person.
It allows construction, manufacturing and curbside retail to reopen with safety precautions, such as social distancing where possible, including wearing face masks.
More than 17-thousand COVID-19 deaths have been recorded in New York City since early March.
Reporter : seungjae86@gmail.com
contents.headline:
New York City enters first phase of four-phase reopening plan
Updated: 2020-06-09 05:56:05 KST

contents.context:
After introducing a police reform bill on Monday, Congressional Democrats kneeled for eight minutes and 46 seconds in memory of George Floyd, whose death at the hands of a police officer sparked worldwide protests.
As well as kneeling, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer called for the passing of the bill, which would lead to increased transparency and limit abuses by law enforcement.
Calling the new bill a "first step", Pelosi said it would also forbid use of chokeholds and ban police from no-knock raids when serving drugs warrants.
Reporter : seungjae86@gmail.com
contents.headline:
House Democrats kneel for George Floyd, introduce police reform bill
Updated: 2020-06-09 05:55:06 KST

contents.context:
U.S. President Trump announced on Sunday that he will be withdrawing the National Guard from Washington D.C., after a weekend of peaceful protests.
CNN reported that around five thousand National Guard troops had been called to patrol Washington D.C.
Trump didn't clearly say if all National Guard forces have been withdrawn, but the Secretary of the Army Ryan McCarthy said that out-of-state Guard forces, which makeup the majority of those deployed in the capital, started going home on Sunday.
Meanwhile, the protests against racism and police brutality that began in the U.S. are spreading around the globe.

"We need to bring it domestically, we need to remember that the UK is not innocent, everything you see around you is built off the backs of black and brown bodies."

At a protest in Bristol, people tore down a statue of slave trader Edward Colston and threw it into Bristol Harbour.
Amid reports of several injuries to police officers in the UK protests, Prime Minister Boris Johnson said that while people have the right to protest, they have no right to attack the police.
Demonstrators also gathered in Liberty Square in Budapest on Sunday and knelt in silence for eight minutes and 46 seconds the length of time Floyd was lying on the ground with a police officer's knee pressed down on his neck.

"It is really sad what is happening in America and I am glad that we are all taking a stand all over the world because enough is enough."

Protests against racism also took place in Spain, Italy, Germany and other countries over the weekend.
Jang Tae-hyun, Arirang News
Reporter : tommyjang@arirang.com
contents.headline:
Trump withdraws National Guard from Washington D.C.; Europe sees Black Lives Matter protests over weekend
Updated: 2020-06-08 17:09:10 KST
